Resonant rectification of fluctuations in a Brownian ratchet
D. G. Luchinsky1,2, M. J. Greenall1,3 and P. V. E. McClintock1
1Department of Physics, Lancaster University, Lancaster LA1 4YB, UK
2Russian Research Institute for Metrological Service, Ozernaya 46, 119361 Moscow,
Russia
3Department of Physics, University of Durham, Durham DH1 3LE, UK
Abstract
Resonant activation, rectification of fluctuations, and current reversal, are
investigated numerically in an asymmetric periodic potential. The results
are compared to recent predictions based on the theory of the logarithmic
susceptibility. Possible applications are discussed.
The phenomenon of resonant activation – a field-induced resonant reduction of the lifetime
of a metastable state – was originally observed in a current-biased Josephson junction [1].
This observation stimulated a wide-ranging discussion [2, 3, 4, 5] of the old theoretical
problem of escape from a potential well in the presence of a nonadiabatic driving field,
i.e. a field whose frequency is comparable with, or higher than, the natural frequency of
oscillation in the bottom of the well (or the reciprocal relaxation time for an overdamped
system). Under these conditions, the system is unable to respond fast enough to the
field to remain in equilibrium with it. The main conclusion was, at first sight, a not
unreasonable one: the high-frequency field would increase the effective temperature of
the system. However, experimentally measured field-induced corrections to the log of the
activation rate, lnW , were found [5] to be ∝ A over a wide range of field amplitude A,
in marked contrast with the ∝ A2 implied by the intuitively appealing physical picture of
field-induced heating. No explanation could be given to this effect at that time.
Recently a new theory has emerged based on the notion of the logarithmic susceptibility
(LS) [6, 7], able to account for these observations. Furthermore, it also predicts new
mechanisms of resonant rectification and a current reversal with changing parameters for
motion in a spatially periodic asymmetric potential, i.e. a ratchet.
1
Published in Phys. Lett. A 273, 316-321 (2000).
In this Letter, we use numerical simulations to investigate resonant activation, resonant
rectification of fluctuations, and current reversal of an underdamped Brownian particle in
a ratchet potential. We show that the results obtained are broadly in agreement with the
predictions of the LS theory – which until now has remained largely untested by either
experiment or numerical simulation – and we discuss the origins of some discrepancies
between theory and experiment. The model investigated was

where U(x+L) = U(x) is a ratchet potential of form U(x) = α sin(x) + β sin(2x+ φ). A
similar model was recently considered in the contexts of quantum ratchets with x(t) being
the coordinate operator (restricted to the adiabatic limit) [8] and voltage rectification by
a SQUID ratchet (restricted to the overdamped limit) [9].
The quantities of primary interest were the period-averaged activation rates W± for
transitions to the right (+) and to the left (−), the net current i.e. the rate of rectification
of fluctuations J = L(W+−W−), and the activation energies S±. In the T → 0 limit noise-
induced escape from a potential well is governed by the slowest decaying eigenmode of
the Fokker-Planck operator corresponding to (1). In this limit the activation rate should,
to leading order, take the WKB form W± ∝ exp(−S±/kT ) where S± is the activation
energy [11]. We have investigated system (1) for a few set of parameters. Here we present
results for the particular shape of potential U(x) = 0.1 sin(x) + 0.049 sin(2x + 0.2) with
Γ = 0.1. It is shown by the bold curves in Fig. 1.
The simulations used a predictor-corrector method of integration and a high-speed
pseudo-random generator [10] for the increment ∆x. The simulation ran continuously, and
the period-averaged rates of escape W± were determined from measurements of the mean
times 〈t〉 to reach the bottom of the neighboring potential well (so that the probability
of returning to the vicinity of original well was negligibly small). The activation energies
S± were then extracted from the measured temperature dependences of W± (e.g. inset of
Fig. 2).
The main results are shown by the data plotted in Figs. 2 and 3. There are several
points to be noted. First, the simulations have yielded linear dependences on the ampli-
2
tude A of the field-induced corrections δS± to the activation energy S± over a wide range
of parameters (Fig. 3), as expected from the LS theory; but there are deviations from
linearity at large and very small A. Secondly, δS± are clearly different for transitions
to the right and to the left, immediately implying a rectification of the fluctuations (see
below). Thirdly, the resonant character of the field-induced activation is clearly demon-
strated (filled circles in Fig. 2) for transitions to the right, though less convincingly for
those to the left (diamonds). Finally, the shape of the former resonance curve is highly
asymmetric: δS± tend (Fig. 2) at low frequencies towards the constant values correspond-
ing to the change of the activation barrier in the static field whereas, for high frequencies,
δS± drop to 0 relatively fast; the data are consistent with, but do not resolve, a weak
additional peak at frequencies close to 1.
To account for these results we recall that, when the temperature is small, a transition
between the potential wells occurs as the result of a large rare fluctuation. Because of the
constraint on the particle dynamics imposed by the deterministic equations of motion,
there is a special energetically optimal way [12] for the fluctuations to drive the particle to
the top of the potential barrier, known as the most probable escape path (MPEP). This
path is experimentally observable [13, 14]. In thermal equilibrium, it is the time-reversed
deterministic relaxational path x±(t) down to the potential minimum at xs, starting from
the left (−) or right (+) adjacent maximum at x±u [12, 13, 14] (see Fig. 1). Thus, x

Addition of the driving force breaks time-reversal symmetry and, in general, the
nonequilibrium MPEP then has to be found numerically by solution of e.g. a variational
problem [6]. According to the LS theory[6, 7], if the driving field is not too strong, the
deviation of the path away from x±(t) can be neglected (see Fig. 1 and the discussion
below). To leading order, the changes in activation energy are given by the maximal work
the force does on the system as it moves along the equilibrium paths so that, for (1)

It can be seen that the susceptibility χ˜(Ω) is given by the Fourier transform of the velocity
x˙±(t) of the system when travelling along the MPEP in the absence of driving. Since
δS±, i.e. the changes of the logarithms of the escape rates W±, are proportional to A
and are expressed in terms of the system characteristics in equilibrium the coeficient of
proportionality is called the logarithmic susceptibility [6, 7] by analogy with standard
linear susceptibility.
Given the WKB-like activation law for the escape probabilities (see above), it is clear
that, although δS± are small, the field-induced corrections to the escape probabilities
depend upon the field amplitude exponentially strongly in the limit T → 0. When the
system fluctuates close to an unstable periodic state, it will remain there for a time ex-
ceeding the field period. Thus, in contrast to the adiabatic case, the transition probability
is not synchronized with the field, and does not depend on time [15].
The results of calculations based on (2) are indicated by the full and dotted curves in
Figs. 2 and 3. It is evident that all the main qualitative features of the simulations are
reproduced by the LS theory. For transitions to the right, there is good agreement between
experiment and simulation over the full frequency range. For transitions to the left there
is of course good agreement in the adiabatic range (Fig. 3(a)), apart from a small offset
associated with the prefactor, but definite disagreement (Fig. 3(b)) for higher frequencies
corresponding to the range for which there is a marked deviation of the dispersion of
δS−/A from the theoretical curve (c.f. Fig. 2).
The deviation from a linear dependence of δS± on A at small amplitudes was also
observed in earlier experiments [5], but an explanation in terms of the dependence of the
prefactor on noise amplitude was given only recently [15]: for the theory to be applicable
without corrections, the field-induced changes to the activation energy must be larger
that the uncertainty due to the finiteness of the temperature. This idea is being tested
experimentally by measurement of δS± in different temperature ranges. The deviation
from δS± ∝ A at large A is caused mainly from going beyond the range of applicability
(δS± ≪ S±) of the theory. These results will be discussed in detail elsewhere [18].
4
The most interesting and important features of resonant activation in a spatially asym-
metric potential are probably the predictions [6] of resonant rectification of the fluctuations
and current reversal. The occurrence of these phenomena in the simulations can immedi-
ately be inferred from the frequency and amplitude dependences of the activation energies
of transitions in opposite directions. Direct measurements of the rectification rate, i.e. of
the net current, are shown in Fig. 4(a), clearly demonstrating both resonance and current
reversal for two different temperatures. As expected from the WKB approximation for
the escape probabilities, the current rises exponentially with temperature.
However, the efficiency of the rectification, defined as the net current J normalized by
the sum of the currents in both directions, i.e. (W+−W−)/(W++W−), is better for low
temperatures as can be seen from Fig. 4(b). Thus if we have e.g. to transport particles
from one side of the ratchet to the other, as in the case of diffusion of cold Rubidium
atoms in an asymmetric optical lattice [16] or surface electromigration [17], the process
works faster at higher temperatures, but more particles will then be traveling in the wrong
direction. Neglecting the dependences of the prefactors on parameters and temperature,
we can compare the efficiency of the rectification with theoretical predictions. It can
be seen from Fig. 4(b) that the agreement is semi-quantitative: as expected, the effect
is much weaker then predicted for the range of frequencies between 0.3 and 0.4 where
deviations of δS− from the theory are most pronounced.
To try to account for the disagreement we note, first, that the transitions to the right
and to the left were measured independently and that the temperature was low enough
that the transition time was always exponentially smaller then the escape time. Thus
the possibility of mutual interference between transitions to the right and to the left
was excluded. We have also investigated possible effects of the stochastic layer near the
saddles which can in principle annihilate the difference between left and right [20]: for
our parameters the effect is insignificant, and no direct transitions between saddles were
observed. For the LS theory to be applicable, kT has to be the smallest parameter of
the problem. Thus for the fluctuations to “feel” the difference in the shape of the MPEP
in opposite directions, kT should be smaller than the characteristic energy loss between
turning points of the MPEP, which ∝ Γ. Temperatures above ∼0.05 tend to eliminate
the asymmetry of the transition rates, the selective effect of the potential is washed
out, and the rectification rate falls (see also e.g. [19]). Even at lower temperatures, the
5
sharp resonances predicted by the theory are found to be smeared out in the numerical
simulations (dotted curve v. open circles data) in Fig. 2.
It is evident from the data in Figs. 2 and Fig. 3(b) that the effect of finite temperature
is apparently different in the two directions. The origin of this difference must presumably
lie in the dynamics of fluctuations along the actual escape trajectories (see Fig. 1) and
is apparently associated with the potential barrier for transitions to the left having a
point of inflection. It can be seen in Fig. 1 that the MPEP to the left moves very close
to the potential and therefore experiences critical slowing down. The effect is local in
coordinate, but it is not local in time. In this region even small deviations of the escape
path away from x−(t) result in significant changes of activation energy and must be taken
into account as corrections to (3). In general, one may expect the theory to work best in
cases where (as for transitions to the right, c.f. Fig. 2) there are no very sharp features
in the shape of the potential. For example, we would expect the theory to work without
correction for the smooth asymmetric potential used in the experiments on the diffusion
of cold Rubidium atoms [16].
In conclusion, we have observed resonant rectification of fluctuations for weakly damped
motion in a Brownian ratchet. The LS theory provides a satisfactory description of the
observed phenomena, but it can become only semi-quantitative near sharp features in the
dispersion of δS±, apparently because these are rounded by the necessarily finite noise
intensity, or by the small deviations of the MPEP from the path in thermal equilibrium.
Note that the effects considered here differ from resonant activation (in the sense of an
optimal noise intensity) in an overdamped system with fluctuating potential barrier [21],
and from rectification of fluctuations in an underdamped system with periodic temper-
ature profile [22]. The work opens new possibilities for controlling the effectiveness of
thermal ratchets. For example, it was noticed in [9] that voltage rectification by an over-
damped SQUID ratchet decreases very fast (exponentially fast [23]) for high frequencies.
Given that its equations of motion [9] are of the form (1) we suggest that the rectification
mechanism discussed above can be applied to e.g. high-frequency voltage rectification by
a SQUID ratchet.
